title: Pairing Univers and Sabon?
content:
As a student, I have been searching for a serif and a sans-serif to use together for my personal collateral. I have been using Univers 45 Light for the sans-serif and have tried in vain to pair it well with a serif. I think I may have found a harmonious match in Sabon. I need some other opinions on this though, so I'm posting the two together for comments. Thanks everyone! -Cory

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20131024043155im_/http:/typophile.com/files/New_5431.jpg)
author: user_1969

comments.content:
Bland nostalgia.  
Try to create a stronger, contemporary personality.
Apart from which, in this one the "Graphic Designer" is stronger than your name, and that's not what you want is it?
I'd say if you're going to use these two together, switch the fonts around and make 'Graphic Designer' a bit smaller. You might even use Univers condensed to keep the lines similar lengths?

<cite>I have been searching for a serif and a sans-serif to use together . . . I have been using Univers 45 Light for the sans-serif and have tried in vain to pair it well with a serif. I think I may have found a harmonious match in Sabon. . . .</cite>

As a graphic design student, you know that it is more than font selection that lets you arrive at the proper mix of harmony and tension. (Don't forget the tension -- without it, all you have is bland.)

You can make Universe 45 Light work with Sabon in a book, where the text is, say, 10-point, and Univers is used for chapter titles, say 20-point. Now, how are you going to make the subheads work -- subheads being roughly the same size as the text? Probably, you're going to have to use Sabon.

The other point I'd make is unless you're going to be a web designer, where I imagine you can't control much of the space, "harmony" will be as much a factor of the white space as type. That, of course, doesn't show with your sample; there is no top, bottom, left, right -- no trim.

Turn it around. Use Sabon for the name and Univers for the title. Maybe a bit conventional but a better solution than the proposal.

. . .  
Bert Vanderveen BNO
[http://typophile.com/node/55767](http://web.archive.org/web/20131024043155/http:/typophile.com/node/55767 "http://typophile.com/node/55767")

Thanks all, I forgot to mention the sample was not for actual use, just showing the two side by side…

@charles\_e: Good point on the white space, I was more focused on how the letterforms were playing with each other, but of course this depends greatly on context!

@Nick Shinn: I actually have no nostaligic or other personal attachments to any one typeface. All situations call for their own solutions, but it is nice for a designer to be able to have certain type to use on their collateral.

Unfortunately "contemporary" doesn't mesh with my dedication to modernism. I'm trying to find a type combination I can use until I die, not until the end of next semester. Also, the idea of a designer having "personality" to their collateral or to have a logo makes no sense to me because one designer is not a company. Why should one person brand themselves? It's your work that should really stand out.

Take a look at the collateral of Massimo Vignelli and Paul Rand (see below): designers whose personal use of type on collateral reflected the "crystal goblet" approach to type: it's the information that is important, not the type itself.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20131024043155im_/http:/typophile.com/files/rand_4279.jpg)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20131024043155im_/http:/typophile.com/files/massimo-1_4996.jpg)

"A new typeface is ideal for the neophyte who is intent on one-upmanship, and who equates the latest with the greatest…Although newness has its place, good design is not merely a question of novelty. The typographer is more important than the type he uses. You can’t blame the type if the typography is poor. It’s like putting the burden on the music when the musician is at fault." -Paul Rand

_Also, the idea of a designer having “personality” to their collateral or to have a logo makes no sense to me because one designer is not a company._

We stand corrected. We assumed you were asking a question. Use TNR.
Correction: it was Cheltenham I used! I think the last time I used Times was in grade school.

skipping the debates for your original question: Univers and Sabon? why not? they sit well enough together. just use them well and let the treatment reflect your typographic awareness.

as for Rand and Vignelli, don't let the modernists hold back your type. their work was nice, but they certainly didn't find the final word in typography.

I find the idea that a designer does not want to brand himself fascinating.

Do you really think that Rand's and Vignelli's typography was not part of their brands?

Fascinated ever further by one who is specifically interested in portraying one's self  
as generic and ubiquitous.

Thanks for your responses everyone, I really appreciate it.

@plainclothes: My case for modernism is one of durability and accessibility. I want to save the real type exploration for my client and/or personal work. This way the collateral has the feeling of being open to anything, and is timeless.

Typography from years past looks dated only when it is ornamental or "cool" at the time it was created. I want something built to last.

@Begsini: I consider brands to be reserved for companies, organizations, studios, products, festivals etc. Individual designers needing brands? I am not convinced that is necessary or even helpful. I am more focused on the work I can do for clients or specific projects, and wanting that to be what I am known for. If my dreams come true and I get to open my own design firm, then it may be branded. Especially being a student, it's all about my portfolio at this point.

I do not think that Rand and Vignelli's type was part of their brands. I don't think they had brands at all, or maybe Vignelli's red type is branded a little more than Rand. But it's their work that when you look at you say "That must be Paul Rand", not their letterhead or business card. While Rand's collateral was modernist, some of his work makes you feel like you're at the circus!

And what is the purpose of a brand? To identify, convey feelings/values and be noticed. When I hand out my business card, which has 8pt black Univers on a yellow background (maybe a brand color eventually, but now just for contrast), People usually say "wow" because they are not used to the modernist approach. This way I stand out. My lack of trying to wow people creates interest because they are used to the opposite in this beveled/embossed/shiny/widget bullshit era.

It is not my goal to be generic or ubiquitous, it is my goal however, to someday establish myself and my work as accessible and capable of taking  
on any design problem.

\>it is my goal however, to someday establish myself and my work as accessible and capable of taking on any design problem.

The trick of this typeface combination is to get rid of Univers … or Sabon :)

To be more serious – your shown example is a carelessness compared to what you wrote after. I suggest doing a new example – 40 pages well set pairing PDF, that illuminates every design problem you are aware of …

Regards

"This way the collateral has the feeling of being open to anything, and is timeless"
 But timeless it exactly isn't – it's modernist nostalgia. Modernism isn't an abstract, floating concept – it's anchored in design history, and its era is over. If you do the same thing today that worked for Paul Rand & Co. back in the day, it _can't_ work that way anymore. The context has shifted. Now if you were to explore how to make something that looks "neutral" _today_, that would be interesting! But "neutral" can't look the same today as it did decades ago. If you want to preserve the spirit of modernism, work to preserve the idea, not the form.
Nice insight, Nina!

\>If you want to preserve the spirit of modernism, work to preserve the idea, not the form.

What is the "idea of moderism", please describe altaira. Is it purification?

Well for one thing (read this thread), there's the belief that form should be transparent, neutral, and ultimately functional; and IMO more worryingly, there is also the belief (which might today seem positivist, reductionist, and naïve) that form _can_ be so neutral and pure and _undesigned_ that it itself stops being relevant/perceived as form.

_I’m trying to find a type combination I can use until I die_

What does this statement say about anyone's future as a designer? Does it appear to preclude future experimentation, learning and growth? Has he finished thinking about type and layout already?

<cite>"The whole point of modernism is to go beyond a time or context."</cite>  
How idealistic. :-)  
I'd think that Modernism, like all eras, like all work ever created, exists within linear time, is rooted in it, and can't transgress it – however much you might like this particular stylistic device to work as well today as back then, it is going to be perceived by at least some initiated minds as taking recourse to a model from a different era.

Sure, you can say screw them, they just don't understand that in my world, Modernism is still Valid today.  
But on the other hand: You're working today.  
Why copy recipes that have grown dusty?

@altaira

I wasn't aware of copying anyone, and you haven't seen my work yet ;-)

What would your advice be? To look at what is popular now and copy it? Wouldn't that be a little hard to keep up with?

Or perhaps I should somehow compile all of graphic design that came out this week and find a way to be different than it?

How can I be different if I am looking at my contemporaries for direction? Or do you think is it better to be the same?

<cite>"you haven’t seen my work yet"</cite>  
That's true. For the record, I'm playing Devil's advocate – trying to push you to see things from a different perspective, and ask deeper questions about what it is you're trying to do.

<cite>"What would your advice be?"</cite>  
Find your own graphic "instincts"; don't define yourself so much in relation to what others do / have done. There isn't just one correct way to solve a given design problem. But if you believe others have already found the Holy Grail, of course there's no need to go on searching.

<cite>I have been searching for a serif and a sans-serif to use together for my personal collateral. I have been using Univers 45 Light for the sans-serif... I think I may have found a harmonious match in Sabon.</cite>

**dear cory.lasser,**

The problem of combining type is normally posed when setting extended text, as in the typesetting of a book, where the serifed face will serve the basic text, and a sans-serif the notes and other marginalia. Here we should not be surprised that harmony is the desired effect.

**Let us turn the microphone to Bringhurst (§6.5.5):**

<cite>Pair serifed and unserifed faces on the basis of their inner structure</cite>

Pay attention to particular letter forms, such the lower-case g (one story or two?). Compare both the roman and italics of both faces (very important). Read up on the faces to see if you can discern a common ancestry. You should quickly conclude that Univers and Sabon fail many of these tests.

The bard himself goes on to recommend pairing Sabon (a Renaissance face designed by Jan Tschichold) with Hans Eduard Meier's [Syntax](http://web.archive.org/web/20131024043155/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/adobe/syntax/).

If you want to look further afield for the sake of ``design'' (or because you are not typesetting a book), you might fancy Martin Majoor's [Scala Sans](http://web.archive.org/web/20131024043155/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/fontfont/ff-scala-sans/) or even his [Seria Sans](http://web.archive.org/web/20131024043155/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/fontfont/seria-sans/), two faces that themselves have a serifed pair that you might consider in lieu of Sabon.

Univers has little to recommend it in this game, but if you admire the work of its designer (Adrian Frutiger), Bringhurst recommends marrying [Méridien](http://web.archive.org/web/20131024043155/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/meridien/) with the eponymous [Frutiger](http://web.archive.org/web/20131024043155/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/adobe/frutiger/).

**Of course, I won't discount the chance that you are pairing two different typefaces in order to make a ``statement.''** This can be done, but you should be very clear about what the statement is.
